comment.author: 30085166@N00
comment._content: Ollie M. James (1871–1918) was a Democratic Representative (1903–1913) and Senator (1913–1918) from Kentucky. Biographical Directory of the United States Congress A Captain C.C. Calhoun of the Kentucky State Militia is mentioned in this 1903 New York Times article. Probably the same Capt. Calhoun in the photo. No clue about the other three, but I suppose it's possible that they were also Kentuckians, posing for a photo with their Senator.

comment.author: 46696233@N00
comment._content: Accorodng to this book: books.google.com/books?id=E2m43HWFcrMC&pg=PA1712&... John R. Downing was big in Kentucky agriculture.

comment.author: 11572312@N00
comment._content: could it be this congressman from Maine: John G. Utterback? en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_G._Utterback

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content:
Thanks to everyone for the additional information and suggestions!  

Harry Angstrom: 

Thanks for the investigative work!  It's difficult to confirm the identity of Mr. Utterback.  

John G. Utterback was not in Congress until 1933, and this photograph was taken in the early 1910's.  He was also closely associated with Maine, and there seems to be a Kentucky connection in this group.

It's possible this is James C. Utterback, cashier of the City National Bank in Paducah, KY, as noted in the same book in which undeadsinatra found information on Downing.  He also might be neither person, and an entirely other Utterback.  In the absence of additional information, we'll retain J. C. Utterback as the identification for now, correcting the typo of 'Utterbeck'.
